header.postText: The Baltimore Uprising is a symptom of a much larger problem!  SIGN THE PLEDGE TO FIGHT RACISM: http://www.bravenewfilms.org/racism SUBSCRIBE http://bit.ly/1JUX3Xv  WATCH OUR FEATURE FILMS FREE: http://bit.ly/1JUX3Xv WATCH MORE: http://bit.ly/1GxWnUe. . Something is wrong when thousands of resumes are mailed to employers with identical information and black-sounding names are 50% less likely to get a call back.  Something is wrong when black people are charged prices roughly $700 higher than white people when buying cars.  Something is wrong when black drivers are twice as likely to get pulled over by the police and black male teens are 21 times more likely to be killed by cops than their white counterparts. Something is wrong when black people are incarcerated at nearly six times the rate of white people.. . And something is wrong when we continue to NOT do anything about it!. SIGN THE PLEDGE TO FIGHT RACISM http://www.bravenewfilms.org/racism. . Educators: use this film in your classroom! http://www.bravenewfilms.org/educators. . Facebook:  http://www.Facebook.com/BraveNewFilms. Instagram:  http://www.Instagram.com/BraveNewFilms. Twitter:  http://www.twitter.com/BraveNewFilms. . DONATE:  https://bravenew.nationbuilder.com/do.... . WATCH OUR FULL FILMS FREE + NEW VIDEOS ALMOST EVERY WEEKDAY: http://bit.ly/1JUX3Xv. . Set up a free screening or house party for any of our films free: http://www.bravenewfilms.org/screenings. . ABOUT BRAVE NEW FILMS. Robert Greenwald and Brave New Films are at the forefront of the fight to create a just America. Using new media and internet video campaigns, Brave New Films has created a quick-strike capability that informs the public, challenges corporate media with the truth, and motivates people to take action on social issues nationwide. Brave New Films' investigative films have scrutinized the impact of U.S. drone strikes; the war on whistleblowers; and Wal Mart's corporate practices.

commentThread.commentText: While I agree that racism happens -- and that people are generally stupid, and therefore often make decisions off of irrelevant and absurd factors (like race) -- I think the general thesis of this video is somewhat is somewhat absurd. You cannot prov e racism with statistics; in other words, disparities don't prove discrimination. So to answer the question, "If this isn 't Racism, then what is?", .. .. "Racis m is racism. That's it." However, I do appreciate that this video is better quality than many out there. In a country full of outrage right now, this video presents its message (true or not) in a generally peaceful, nonviolent, and reasonable manner. Thank you. [^and yes, there are points that I agree on too, so I appreciate that also. For example, I totally agree that the best and only true way to co unter racism is by peacefully correcting the thinking at its core, not with outrage, violence, or government action.]

All of them appear valid points, but many of them pretty blatantly leave out other contributing aspects that also factor in with race and create very obvious arguing points (Police more often than not cannot see someone's race before they pull them over, equal marijuana use but what led to each person getting caught, etc.). You've already convinced the people who agree with you, but using one-sided arguments isn't going to convince people who don't. Presenting the whole argument of each topic with a brief synopsis, and acknowledging the other talking points while still emphasizing what can't be explained by anything other tha n race is what's going to convince rational people. Irrational people won't be convinced regardless. Sometimes people just have never had the full facts and statistics clearly presented to them and it's all they needed, but incomplete arguments aren't going to do that. Anyways just my thoughts.

Racism is the lowest, most crudely primitive form of collectivism. It is the notion of ascribing moral, social or political significance to a man's genetic lineage—the notion that a man's intellectual and characterological traits are produced and transmitted by his internal body chemistry. Which means, in practice, that a man is to be judged, not by his own character and actions, but by the characters and actions of a collective of ancestors. Racism claims that the content of a man's mind (not his cognitive apparatus, but its content) is inherited; that a man's convictions, values and character are determined before he is born, by physical factors beyond his control. This is the caveman's version of the doctrine of innate ideas—or of inherited knowledge—which has been thoroughly refuted by philosophy and science. Racism is a doctrine of, by and for brutes. It is a barnyard or stock-farm version of collectivism, appropriate to a mentality that differentiates between various breeds of animals, but not between animals and men.Like every form of determinism , racism invalidates the specific attribute which distinguishes man from all other living species: his rational facult y. Racism negates two aspects of man's life: reason and choice, or mind and morality, replacing them with chemical predestination. -Ayn Rand

Also take a look at t his...Black people are the most vulnerable cogs in the wheel, and remain in a permanent state of crisi s.  If Black people remain vulnerable, no one in America's so-called democracy is safe.  The problem is institutio nalized racism, in a country which fails to acknowledge there is a crisis.  And yet, another study on a major American city sounds the alarm on the barrier s facing Black people. This time it's Black men in Pittsburgh. The study from the Urban Institute is titled, 'Barriers & Bridges: An Action Plan for Overcoming Obstacles and Unlocking Opportu nities for African American Men in Pittsburgh.'  The 67-page report found that in the post-industrial economy in which Pittsburgh is thriving, based particularly on a shift from manufacturing to finance and health services, hiring practices that shut out people of colo r have kept Black men from economic opportunity. The Urban Institute Report focuses primarily on documenting the racial dispari ties between Black and white men in their access to jobs, financial services, and business development opportunities. It also identified structural barriers in the form of policies, practices, and norms that help maintain racial gaps. 'Though economic disadvantage befalls people of all races an d ages, young African American men have borne a disproportionate share of the burden of Pittsburgh's economic change,' the report's authors wrote. 'Although never fully equal, the well-paying manufacturing jobs that many African American men were able to secure with only a high school diploma (or sometimes less education) have virtually disappeared, leaving many men with few alternatives for adequately supporting a family.' According to the study, city leaders realize the need to change the way Pittsburgh does business, which contributes to the considerable racial disparities.  The city wants to attract more employers and industries, and suffers from a 'mid-level skills gap,' in which employees have been on the job for either 40 or more years, or less than five years.  Further, the city's interest in racial inclusion is driven by younger workers, who want to live in places that reflect Ameri ca's racial and ethnic diversity. Intergenerational mobility was identified as a factor leading to racial exclusion, as unions kept out African-American workers, leaving Black children lacking in the resources their white peers receive to acquire the skills the new w orkforce demands.  Black men in particular, have suffered from structural barriers, including current institutional practices, geographic segregation, social isolation from critical networks, and economic and other accumulated disadvantages resulting from a lack of access to employment, education, and other opportunities. In Pittsburgh, the consequences of these b arriers are clear.  African-American men are 11.4 percent of men ages 18 to 64 in the Pittsburgh region, yet they are a mere 5.4 percent of the region's adult male workforce.  The report also found that in many key industries, Black workers find themselves at the bottom of the pay scale.  Moreover, the report not es that 'Pittsburgh's African American men have historically and disproportionately faced unprecedented barriers to economic opportunities' among people liv ing in the region. For Black men with at least a high school diploma, the unemployment rate between 2007 and 2011 was 12.2 percent, more than double that of whites (5.1 percent).  In addition, Black men are far more likely to live at or below the poverty level. 'Structural barriers such as the expense of job training programs, online job applications (for men without easy access to a computer), and insufficient financial collateral to qualify for a business loan are very real for men who disproportionately struggle to make ends meet,' the report noted. 'You have people who are disproportionately touched by the criminal justice system — sometimes unfairly — and they are disproportionately excluded from health care and other security-sensitive sectors,' Urban Institute fellow Margaret Simms told the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. Simms called the city 'one of the most segregated metropolitan communities in the country,' split along historical racial divides that still shape neighborhoods, the workforce and professional and social networks. This latest study is but one of numerous reports that chronicle the impact of institutional ra cism on the well-being of African-Americans.  For example, a recent study found that in Bal timore, banks are cheating Black people out of m ortgages based primarily on race rather than income.  Companies use the court system to pursue c ollection lawsuits to target Black communities and squeeze them financially.  Further, due to race-based predatory lending, Black homeowners lost wealth as whites gained wealth, cutting them out of the so-called American Dream.  The police financially exploit communities of color, as one Oklahoma study found that Blacks and other minorities accounted for two-thirds of the cash seizures by law enforcement. In addition, the racial disparities in health care are evident, as Blacks and Latinos receive lower quality care and are made to wai t longer to see the doctor, and Black children are less likely to receive crucial pain medication than whites in the emergency room. The studies are endless, all with similarly disappointing and alarming findings.  The reports will continue to mount if America fails to address the fundamentals of systemic racial discrimination, and seek to eradicate them immediately.

Now here's an interesting scientific fact, I read in an issue of "The World of Science" about a prediction that in a 1000 years or longer human race will evolve in a way that we will all have more or less unified skin tone and that will be beige or olive beige (which i s nothing less than returning to our supposed origins of the first developed civilizations "the white man" comes from). It helps when white people engage other white people on the subject of racism. Being outspoken about these issues is important for propagating positive anti -racist values through your circles of friends etc. However, sometimes that will fail, and you won't be able to change some people's minds. Up to you to decide if you want to remain their friends. How strong are your morals? The best thing for fixin g racism is actually an attitude of indifference towards races, as opposed to an attitude of strong recognition of injustice (even though that's counter-intuitive). The problem with the second thing, is that it keeps bringi ng race into focus as if it's something that matters - when in reality, it doesn 't. Race should not matter for any situation, period. That's the logical stance. Making people into victims will actually always generate some backlash - this is a weird psychological thing that's part of human nature on larger scales. If a pers on is racist, the best kind of social pressure towards them should be along the lines of: "What the hell? Why does that even matter? Why you do care? Don't you have anything better to do? commentThread.commentText: First I would like to say that this video brings up many disturbing tends that exist within the United States. Racism is illogical and therefore should be done away with. Racism is also pervasive and has never been truly eliminated in any society ever.  We humans will always do that which benefits us. So I propose we solve the problem like an economist solves problems. We find the trends, we investigate those trends, and we conclude rational decisions.  I f racism is so pervasive, we must ask why. Now I'm going to piss off a bunch of SJW's here, and that's okay with me ;)  Most people kn ow racism is wrong, most people don't admit to be ing racist, yet people act racist. Look at the statistics, and realize people are often unaware or unwilling to admit if they are sec retly racist. This isn't a justification, its a trend, lets ask ourselves why. Has morality, or the "right thing to do" ever really steered people away from behaviors they wanted to engage in? I don't think so (think to the number of people who claim each other to be immoral) and if you're willing to accept that premise then we can conclude there is something confounding causing the issue. Telling peopl e that racism is unethical, useless, wrong, immoral, illegal or stupid doesn't seem to convince people to give up that bad habit. Why is that? This is another trend. Educating them from a young age seems to make people more tolerant, yet in the end they still fall into those same bad habits, albeit much less publicly. Why is that? Are there any other behaviors we could associate with a population tha t mimics racism? I believe there are several , chiefly nationalism, class-ism, affiliations to political parties, ect. People can be moved to great emotion and illogical behavior by these stark divides. Another trend. I could keep going but I want to postulate this. If we start attacking this problem online, and start discussing with one another constructively the things we think, we as a democracy might be able to formulate a solution that our children can finally enjoy. Instead we feed trolls, point fingers, call names, bog ourselves down in conjecture and commit logical fallacies, all to feed an internal need of ego. Why is that?  I think the Internet is this country's only real shot at fixing this problem. Schools won't or can't. Government won't or can't. Businesses don't bother trying much at all. We can though. We can debate, discuss and problem solve together and make a difference. I just say that whats going on down there in the comments is atrocious.

commentThread.commentText: Your "experiment" is a failure because you are making a fundamental mistake in your assumption that all factors are equal between all races (not BOTH races). You negate the historical actions of certain people. Humans have the natural ability to learn from the past and assess threats based on previous experience. What you are asking people to do is ignore that natural instinct and take the time to assess each person individually. Yes, that would be ideal in a perfect world, but our world is far from perfect. What you are asking people to do is akin to asking a gazelle not to fear a lion because THAT PARTICULAR lion didn't kill his family. Sure, there is a chance that the gazelle will be just fine and THAT PARTICULAR lion isn't going to hurt him, but it is unreasonable to expect the gazelle to take that chance. I am fully aware that you will disagree with these statements because you want to believe that all people are good and that we just haven't given certain people a fair chance or that they are at some sort of a disadvantage. But you're wrong. I'm sorry but the truth can be inconvenient at times. People usually act the way they do because of past experience, either their own or that of others. It doesn't make them right, but it is a natural instinct designed to protect them. In a perfect world, all men would be treated equally and the color of one's skin would be no more important than the color of their eyes, however as long as certain groups cast a negative light upon themselves (i.e. Baltimore looters) then there will always be a perpetuation of stereotypes. Stereotypes created by the actions of a particular group.  Lastly, please don't blame lack of opportunity. Minorities in America receive the vast majority of public assistance and have many educational opportunities available to them based solely on the color of their skin. Racism is a two way street.

Hi. I'm going to get so much hate for this, but I don't really care. I'm a huge statistics/experiment junkie so I thought I'd review all of the sources in the video in terms of reputability and other points. Resume Study - Solid. No other key things I can find. Car Dealership Study - Solid, but I don't get why you sourced a NYT article and not the original study. Anyways, the study creators' saw this not as a "I hate these people so I will charge them more" thing - but that the car dealers automatically assumed that white people would have higher reservations on prices. Traffic Studies/Meta Analysis' - Solid. No other key things I can find. Housing Study - Solid. No difference in appointments or single properties shown. 17% difference is in being shown multiple homes. Similar to the authors' of the car dealership study, these authors' wondered out loud if this is a (intentional or not) statistical analysis based on likelihood of a certain race to end up buying. Marijuana Study - Solid. No other key things I can find. Heart Procedure Study - Findings seem to be controversial. Previous study authors actually came back and wrote a rebuttal to the study indicating that this wasn't at all what the study found. Furthermore, recommendations have been argued to be based on statistical medical/physiological differences between blacks and whites. Legislator Experiment - Solid for when legislators were white but interestingly if the legislator was a minority - they responded to "black" sounding names more often. --------- Overall, basically everything in this video was on point... with some minor exceptions/notes.... video creators' y'all should be sure to include the study links in the description - also your source notes often have wrong titles/years/authors.

Granted, that is almost triple the percentage of white Americans who live in poverty, but to try and intimate that poverty and blackness are synonymous is inaccurate. I myself am an upper middle-cla ss black adult who was born and raised in an upper middle-class household to parents who had themselves been born and raised in middle-class households by their own parents who had what passed for black middle-class origins in the Ji m >Crow South. I am not an anomaly, or some kind of rare unic orn of black success. Most black Americans are middle-class, and some of us are even wealthy, which means that we are getting educations and working and supporting ourselves and our families. Don't try to pretend that "ghetto" culture or "thug" culture is the full scope of black culture. Most of us are just regular people who have the same relative values and work ethic as the next (white/asian/latino/whatever) schmoe, except that we often have people asking us "why can't your people just get over sl avery and racism and pull it together?" Some of us are having a harder time of it. You could help, if you want to; if you care. You may not believe it, but many poor black children are not ever told by anyone who matters to them that they can be smart and successful. They don't see many real life examples of hard work resulting in economic stability. They have downtrodden parents who work long hours at low-wage jobs (or sometimes don't work at all, for various legitimate or illegitimate reasons,) and are one missed or shorted paycheck from living on the street. They have jaded teachers who expect them to under-perform and who shrug their shoulders when they fail (many of the optimistic teachers burn out or move on to better school districts ASAP.) They have peers who perpetuate the idea that education is for white people by calling any black child who speaks properly and likes to read/study a fake/phony/oreo/race traitor, and humiliate them or ostracize them until they fall back into what's "expected" of them. Oh, or playing pro ball, because blacks may not be too smart, but they sure can run fast./sarcasm All of that is demoralizing, and some people are strong enough to overcome it and succeed anyway, but most pe ople (of whatever race) tend to take the path of least resistance, only working just hard enough to maintain the status-quo. A lot of the people who come to America from other countries are already of the mindset that America is a place where, if you work hard enough, you can succeed. They are already the very rare kind of person who would do WHATEVER it takes to have a good life, as opposed to the billions of average people all over the world who die in the same relative income bracket as the one into which they were born. Most people born into wealth stay wealthy, most people born in the middle class stay in the middle class, and most people born into poverty stay poor. That is a tr uth, whatever your race/ethnicity/nationality.

@Christan Price Tim Wise actually brings up a good point. In my initial comment I said as a white person I am more likely than a black person to be the victim of interracial violence. But this was a very empty comment; what do I mean when I say "as a white person"? Do I mean as a member of the group of all white humans on Earth? Do I mean as a member of the group of all white Americans? Surely Swiss people, Nigerians, and white residents of Concord, New Hampshire are each barely likely at all to be the victims of interracial violence. So let me now be more precise. Between white people who frequently interact with blacks and black people who frequently interact with whites, I as such a white person am significantly more likely than m y black counterpart to be the victim of interracial violence. Tim Wise points out that any giv en black American is 2.75 times more likely than a white American to be interracially murdered. This is true, but what if we redrew the lines for a moment and considered American and/or continen tal African victims of interracial murder. Then clearly blacks would be significantly less likely to be interracially murdered as continental Africans barely experience it at all. Now if we redrew the lines again to consider American an d/or African and/or European victims of interracial murder, then at this point it might come out closer to equal probabilities for interracial murder. The point at which Wise's argument breaks down is the point at which he ignores the tens of millions of whites in the Midwest and in New England who don't interact with blacks at all and thus bring down the white victimhood rate down tremendously. These particular millions of whites do not have black counterparts who can avoid interacting with the other race in the same proportion. These whites might as well be on another continent, or on Mars, for all the good they do in helping us understand the problem of victimhoods. So in my opinion the best place to really see what's going on is individual cities that hav e large black and white populations. I live in Atlanta, which is about as evenly-split as it gets. Tim Wise says I shouldn't fear that one in fifty black men will do something violent in a given year, but I pass by fifty black people every day on public transport. And I have no idea what Wise is trying to prove with the W-B and B-W encounter relative percentages; it makes no sense to me. I would think that every one W-B encounter would equal one B-W encounter, so (W-B encounters) = (B-W encounters) at all ti mes. So if black people and white people were equally violent, the number of W-B crimes would be equal to the number of B-W crimes, period. I have no idea why he thinks I should be pleased that the rate of black on white crime isn't quite as high as he thinks it would be if only blacks were even more violent to whites to reflect how violent they are to o ther blacks; black-on-white still accounts for MOST of the interracial crime, just like he says. Every time I walk past a black man on the sidewalk late at night, he doesn't know me and I don't know him. There is a microscopic chance that he will be victimized by me as I pass him by. There is a microscopic chance that I will be victimized by him as he passes by. But my microscopic chance to be victimized is about 5 times worse than his. Over time you see these microscopic cross se ctions add up; black people are responsible for almost all the crime and violence in Atlanta, despite being only a bit over half of the residents.

A few of the facts presented in the video are studied (particularly the examples dealing with resumes and car dealership) in detail in the book Blink by Malcolm Gladwell. It should be noted that those neither those who conducted the studies nor Malcolm Gladwell himself, who is half Jamaican, believe that conscious racism is at fault for the actions of the employers and car dealers, respectively. Rather, it appears that the human brain has absorbed the information presented to it on an unconscious level and subsequently reacts differently when dealing with African-Americans as opposed to how it reacts to dealing with other races. I suggest going to the Harvard website and taking a few IATs, which test your preferences between races on an unconscious level. The author of the book, regardless of his Jamaican background, found his unconscious to be preferential towards whites over blacks, showing just how pervasive the stereotypes presented to us can be. Its a good read, particularly when paired with Victor Rios' Unpunished, in which the author shadows at risk and gang involved youth in an ethnography focused on the results of hypercriminalization in Oakland, CA. They offer a lot of insight on the topic of race in America today.

As a white man, I have seen prejudice and racism with my own eyes. I remember I went to an interview for a dog training job at Petco. It was a group interview, consisting of me (a white man) and two other individuals (a black > woman, and a black man). Both of those individuals had extensive dog training experience, and I had none whatsoever. During the interview I began to feel very insignificant and less qualified than the other two individuals. They were both professional and I was certain that either one of them would get the job before me. I could tell, however, that during the interview, the (white) interviewer seemed to be favoring me over the others, he looked at me much more, was more engaging, etc. Two days after the interview I got a call back saying that he'd like to offer me the dog training job. Wow! I mean, damn.....I felt really bad. It was quite clearly a case of prejudice, he was favoring me because I was a white male like him. Anyway, it was pretty messed up. I declined to accept the job and he sounded really disappointed. Hopefully he offered the job to one of the other candidates. Prejudice and racism exists, yes. But you have to realize that it seems to come from all gro ups. Racism is "natural" in the sense that humans tend to group together by likeness, the re is nothing wrong with this, but unfortunately in today's society we need to blend together more than we need to isolate one another. Also, black people need to make a distinction between racism and prejudice. Often what is called "racism" is really just mild prejudice. I doubt many people are truly racist, but many are prejudiced. As a white man, I have been on the receiving end of prejudice. Yes, I have. For example, there is a Bangladeshi restaurant nearby that I used to go to but I don't anymore because every time I went in, the majority Bangladeshi patrons who dine there would stare at me and kind of give me this look like, "What is this guy doing here?" Even the staff would treat me kind of coldly while they treated the other patrons with warmth and gentility. I'm sorry, but that's prejudice. If minority groups feel like they are treated unfairly by whites, than they need to avoid treating white people unfairly when the white person is in the minority. Also, nepotism's tend to form among minority groups. Why aren't they being pressured to be more inclusive? Why is it that neighborhoods tend to break down among racial lines? The Asians congregate with the Asians, the Indians congregate with the Indians, the blacks with the blacks, etc. It's not only white people seeking their own, it's every other group as well, but yet it's white people who get all the bad rep. I have to say that Asians get very mistreated in society, blacks don't like them and Asians don't like blacks. Why aren't either of these groups under pressure to change? You see, ev erybody is racist, but it's only white's that we hear about. Asians discriminate against blacks all the time. .... Also, black people are some of the most homophobic people in society, and it's odd to hear this group who complains about being discriminated against to then turn right around and discriminate against gays. White people discriminate for sure, I acknowledge that. But there's plenty of pie to go around and blame to be put on everyone, not just whites. Gandhi said "Be the change you wish to see in the world." It is incum bent upon all ethnic groups to put down their prejudice and be the change they want to see.
I'm sick of this "Blacks vs Whites", what about all the other Asians, Hispanics, and other "Brown" people?

He paired with Marianne Bertrand to co-author the 2003 Chicago Field Study. Using him in two of your sources for racism is biased. He even cited the Cardiac Catheterization from 1999 and the 2011 Yale University field experiment with state legilators which I'll get to in a bit. The sources being used are all from the same person, this video is extremely biased in the sources it used, which destroys its credentials and credibility to someone who looks at it objectively and scientifically. The part in his article that I do agree with is unconsc ious racism, which is a media issue created to deepen racial divides. 3) Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development: Housing Discrimination Against Racia l and Ethnic Minorities 2012. [LINK]  This statistic pulled from the article by the video is picking and choosing. If you read the entire article it supports that blatant discrimination, such as this video suggests, has dropped dramatically and is nearly non-existent, but some forms of indirect discrimination exist. However, to claim that all home purchasing minorities are expe rience racism at 17% rates is misleading without looking at the article as a whole and discussing its findings. 4) The Sentencing Project Uneven Justice: State rates of Incarcera tion by Race and Ethnicity. [LINK] To simply state that blacks are incarcerated 6 times the rates of white people are is another misleading statement. This is more of a political topic in which we delve into why more crime is committed by blacks than whites, thus substantiating the statistic this video used without discussing the reasoning behind it. To simply throw it out there and claim racism is ignorant and biased in and of itself. 5) New England Journal of Medicine: Effect of Race and Sex on Physicians Recommendations for Cardiac Catheters. 1999 First of all why are we claiming racism in 2015 by citing an article done nearly two decades ago in 1999... Second, the statement th e video made "doctors did not inform black patients as often as white ones about an important heart procedure" is another generalization and misleads people. Actually read the article, even though it is nearly 20 years old, and see how they did their study and what their findings were as a whole. Don't make a broad misleading statement to support th at it attests to racism today. 5) Yale University Field Experiment on State Legislators. [LINK] As stated before, the same author from this article co authored the first source, and wrote the second. Using one person as a source for at least 3 of your citations in your video completely destroys any credibility you're trying to portray. The entire video is biased, makes generalized statements without looking at actual facts, and claims racism today without using viable current studies.

commentThread.commentText: This video explains things perfectly, and why ANYONE with a brain and a sense of justice, should be bothered with what is going on. Hopefully this video will serve to dispel the notion that systemic "quite" racism no longer exists, and how it still serves to perpetrate racial inequality.
Yup so true!!

The first example in the video cites a New York Times article by Sendhil Mullainathan, who cites a study done by Ian Ayers and Peter Siegelman, titled: " Race and Gender Discrimination in Bargaining for a New Car".  The Joy of Economics: Making Sense out of Life by Robert J. Stonebraker, Winthrop University points this important information out: "African-American buyers were charged the same price differentials by African-American dealers as they were by white dealers.  Female customers were treated just as poorly by female salespeople as they were by male salespeople.  Neither th e race nor t he gender of dealers and/or salespeople seemed to matter.   Ayres and Siegelman conclude that statistical discrimination is the real culprit.  Blatant bigotry is not the cause." Be sure to actually look up the sources that are being given to you by this video's creators.

replies.commentText: @Joshua M the Ayers & Sigelman paper in AER in 1995 states that difference in price are attributable to "dealer inferences about consumers reservation prices." Thus, it could be argued that the debate is HOW did the dealers arrive at their conclusions about the different reservation prices? Racism certainly can be an issue because it was never explicitly tested for in their sample.

commentThread.commentText: In a nutshell.

This is a good video, and pertinent.
